list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The graph of $y=f(x)$ for $−3≤x≤4$ is shown in the following diagram.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/0d3ba1ec-6f76-4f87-8209-56090c4506bd/AA1269-q.JPEG)



Write down the value of $f(2)$. [1]


Let $g(x)=2f(x)−1$ for $−3≤x≤4$.


On the axes above, sketch the graph of $g$. [2]



Hence determine the value of $(g∘f)(2)$. [1]



Hence solve the equation $(f∘g)(x)=0$ when $x>0$. [1]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $f(x)$ when $x=2$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/c72e725f-d507-4121-a17b-66ecf4396773/AA1269-a1.JPEG)


Hence $f(2)=1​$.
$$$​A1​$$$


The function $f(x)$ is mapped to $g(x)$ by two transformations.
By considering $g(x)=2f(x)−1$, we can see there is a $vertical stretch by a scale factor of2$ and a $vertical shift down1unit$.
The vertical stretch ($y=2f(x)$) is shown in blue below.
Note that the vertical distance from the $y$-axis of every point on the curve is doubled.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/41efdd00-fe18-4d90-9631-5f9a1149eef3/AA1269-a2.JPEG)


Then the vertical shift is shown in green ($y=2f(x)−1$) .
Note that every point on the blue curve is shifted vertically down $1$ unit.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/51af6fb3-badd-4b23-be15-204b433352af/AA1269-a3.JPEG)


Correct local minimum at $(−2,1)$
$$$​A1​$$$
Correct $y$-intercept at $(0,5)$
$$$​A1​$$$


From part (a) we know that $f(2)=1$.
$$$(g∘f)(2)​=g(f(2))​$$$
Hence
$$$​=g(1)=3​$$$
Hence $(g∘f)(2)=3​$.
$$$​A1​$$$
Here is the graph of $g(x)$ showing that $g(1)=3$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/d9677404-62bb-4ed2-94e5-6951c683bf6f/AA1269-a4.JPEG)




We have the equation $(f∘g)(x)=0$. The L.H.S. is a composite function which can be rewritten
$$$(f∘g)(x)​=f(g(x))​$$$
Here we can see that $g(x)$ is the inner function and $f(x)$ is the outer function, meaning that the output of $g$ will be the input of $f$.
By considering the graph of $f(x)$ we see that when $x=3$ then $f(x)=0$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/034fc9e0-20b2-4311-a983-f42b00ef90fa/images/1d572c1f-c5a2-405c-ad40-af9f075ac80d/AA1269-a5.JPEG)


This means in order to have an output of $0$, the input must be $3$.
$$$f(g(x))=0f(3)=0​$$$
Therefore we need to find the value of $x$, where $x>0$, such that $g(x)=3$.
From part (c), we know that $g(1)=3$, and we can see that this is the only possible solution when $x>0$.
Hence if $x>0$ and $(f∘g)(x)=0$ then $x=1​$.
$$$​A1​$$$

list.markScheme:

$$$​f(2)=5​​A1​$$$


Using our previous answer and the point $(5,3)$ on $g(x)$ we can write

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Let $f(x)=x3$ and $g(x)=2x−1$, for $x∈R$.


Find $g−1(x)$. [2]



Find $(g∘f)(x)$. [2]



Solve the equation $(g∘f)(x)=0$. [2]
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation $(g∘g−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=g−1(x)$, we get
$$$g(g−1(x))g(y)2y−12yy​=x=x=x=x+1=2x+1​​$$$
$$$g−1(x)=2x+1​​$$$


We have
$$$(g∘f)(x)​=g(f(x))=g(x3)=2x3−1​​$$$


Solving the equation $(g∘f)(x)=0$ for $x$, we obtain
$$$2x3−1​=0[by part (b)]​$$$
$$$x≈0.794​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Let $f(x)=x2+2$ and $g(x)=x−3$, for $x∈R$.


Find $f(3)$. [2]



Find $(g∘f)(3)$. [2]



Find $g−1(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $f(x)=x2+2$ for $x=3$, we get
$$$f(3)​=32+2=9+2=11​​$$$


Evaluating $(g∘f)(x)=g(f(x))$ for $x=3$, we obtain
$$$(g∘f)(3)​=g(f(3))=g(11)[by part (a)]=11−3=8​​$$$


If we solve the equation $(g∘g−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=g−1(x)$, we find
$$$g(g−1(x))g(y)y−3y​=x=x=x=x+3​$$$
$$$g−1(x)=x+3​$$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Let $f(x)=4x−2$, for $x∈R$.


The graph of a linear function $g$ is perpendicular to the graph of $f$ and passes through the origin. Find an expression for $g(x)$.[2]



The graph of a linear function $h$ is parallel to the graph of $f$ and passes through the point $(3,4)$. Find an expression for $h(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
The slope of $f$ is $mf​=4$, then $mg​=−41​$ is the slope of the function $g$ that is perpendicular to $f$, we have
$$$y−y1​y−0y​=m(x−x1​)=−41​(x−0)=−41​x​$$$
Therefore, $g(x)=−41​x​.$


The slope of the function $h$ is $mh​=4$ because $h$ is parallel to the graph $f$. We have,
$$$y−y1​=m(x−x1​)y−4y−4y=4x−8​=4(x−3)=4x−12​$$$
Therefore, $h(x)=4x−8​.$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Consider the line $L1​$ which passes through the points $A(−4,−4)$ and $B(8,−1)$.

Find the gradient of the line $L1​$. [1]


Line $L2​$ is perpendicular to $L1​$ and passes through the point $(−a,2a)$ where $a∈R$.

Given that $L2​$ intersects the $y$-axis at $y=2a−3$, find the value of $a$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Using the formula for the gradient of a line
$$$m​=x2​−x1​y2​−y1​​​$$$
we can find the gradient of $L1​$
$$$m1​​=8−(−4)−1−(−4)​=123​=41​​​A1​$$$


As $L2​$ is perpendicular to $L1​$ we can find the gradient of $L2​$ using the formula
$$$m1​×m2​41​×m2​m2​​=−1=−1=−4​(A1)​$$$
We can form an equation, using the gradient formula, and solve for $a$.
Substituting in $m2​$ and the points $(−a,2a)$ and $(0,2a−3)$ we get
$$$m2​−4−4−4aa​=x2​−x1​y2​−y1​​=0−(−a)(2a−3)−2a​=a−3​=−3=43​​​(M1)A1​$$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Let $f(x)=(x+2)3$, for $x∈R$.


Find $f−1(x)$. [3]



Let $g$ be a function so that $(f∘g)(x)=27x6$.

Find $g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation $(f∘f−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=f−1(x)$, we get
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)(y+2)3y+2y​=x=x=x=3x​=3x​−2​$$$
$$$f−1(x)=3x​−2​$$$


If we solve the equation $(f∘g)(x)=27x6$ for $y=g(x)$, we
obtain
$$$f(g(x))f(y)(y+2)3y+2y​=27x6=27x6=27x6=3x2=3x2−2​$$$
$$$g(x)=3x2−2​$$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
The equation of a line $L1​$ is $2x+3y=−5$.


Find the gradient of $L1​$. [2]



A second line, $L2​$, is perpendicular to $L1​$.


State the gradient of $L2​$. [1]



The point P$(4,0)$ lies on $L2​$.


Find the equation of $L2​$, giving your answer in the form
$ax+by+d=0$, where $a,b,d∈Z$. [2]



The point Q is the intersection of $L1​$ and $L2​$.

Find the coordinates of Q. [3]
list.markScheme:
If we rewrite the equation of $L1​$ in the form $y=mx+c$, we
have
$$$2x+3y3yy​=−5=−2x−5=−32​x−35​​$$$
Hence the gradient of $L1​$ is
$mL1​​=−32​​$


The gradient of $L2​$ is
$$$mL2​​​=−mL1​​1​[since L2​⊥L1​]=−(−2/3)1​=23​​​$$$


Using the point-gradient formula with P$(4,0)$ and $m=3/2$, we get
$$$y−y1​y−02y​=m(x−x1​)=23​(x−4)=3x−12​$$$
$$$0=3x−2y−12​$$$


We have
$$$L1​L2​​:2x+3y=−5(1):3x−2y=12(2)​$$$
Solving
the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $x$ and $y$, we
obtain
$$$xy​==​2−3​​$$$
Hence the coordinates of Q are
$(2,−3)​$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Let $f(x)=x3+1$ and $g(x)=x−2$, for $x∈R$.


Find $f(2)$. [2]



Find $f−1(x)$. [2]



Solve $(f∘g)(x)=0$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $f(x)=x3+1$ for $x=2$, we get
$$$f(2)​=23+1=8+1=9​​$$$


Solving the equation $(f∘f−1)(x)=x$ for $y=f−1(x)$,
we find
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)y3+1y3y​=x=x=x=x−1=3x−1​​$$$
$$$f−1(x)=3x−1​​$$$


Solving the equation $(f∘g)(x)=0$ for $x$, we obtain
$$$f(g(x))f(x−2)(x−2)3+1x−2​=0=0=0=3−1​[=−1]​$$$
$$$x=1​$$$

Find $g(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
If we draw the graph of $y=f(x)$ for $−3≤x≤2$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/0c8cb343-6319-4c4b-bd01-6881dfb5c2ff/a0ce7feb5a9182c2d088b3711cfba75a324b8033.svg)

Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$(0.996,0)​$

$$$y​=f(0)=0.2e0+2−4≈−2.52​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$(0,−2.52)​$




We have
$$$g(x)​=−f(x−1)+2=−[0.2e(x−1)+2−4]+2=−0.2ex+1+6​​$$$

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Let $f(x)=2ln(x+2)​$, for $x>−2$. The diagram below shows
part of the graph of $f$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ca4f0d8-2c1b-4539-b90a-140704aebde0/images/41cb6db4-c952-44a9-a5d0-dc5fd6907d15/0b26b0e195f4a087c10216491d624f903712efff.svg)




Find the coordinates of:


the $x$-intercept;


the $y$-intercept. [2]





Find the equation of the vertical asymptote to the graph of $f$.
[2]



Find the area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the
$x$-axis and
the $y$-axis. [2]
list.markScheme:
Solving the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we have
$$$2ln(x+2)​x​=0=−1[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$(−1,0)​$


Evaluating $f(x)=2ln(x+2)​$ for $x=0$, we have
$$$f(0)​=2ln2​≈0.347​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$(0,0.347)​$




We have
$$$x→0+lim​lnxx→−2+lim​ln(x+2)x→−2+lim​f(x)​=−∞=−∞=−∞​$$$
Hence
the equation of the vertical asymptote is
$x=−2​$


The area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the $x$-axis
and the $y$-axis is
$$$A​=∫−10​2ln(x+2)​dx≈0.193 units2​[by using G.D.C.]​$$$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined by $f(x)=32x+1​$, for
$−14≤x≤13$.


Write down the range of $f$. [2]



Find an expression for $f−1$. [2]



Write down the domain and range of $f−1$. [2]
list.markScheme:
We have
1 $f$ is continuous and increasing;
2 $f(−14)=−3$ and $f(13)=3$.
Hence the range of $f$ is
$[−3,3]​$


If we solve the equation $(f∘f−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=f−1(x)$, we get
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)32y+1​2y+1y​=x=x=x=x3=2x3−1​​$$$
Hence an
expression for $f−1$ is
$f−1(x)=2x3−1​​$


The domain and range of $f−1$ are
$$$domain:range:​[−3,3]​[−14,13]​​$$$

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
The function $f$ is given by $f(x)=x2−164x2−128​$, for
$x=±4$.


Prove that $f$ is an even function. [2]





Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$.


Write down the range of $f$. [5]
list.markScheme:
For any $x∈R$, $x=±4$, we have
$$$f(−x)​=(−x)2−164(−x)2−128​=x2−164x2−128​=f(x)​$$$
Hence $f$ is an even function.




If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we
have

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
The ocean pressure, $P$, under sea level can be modelled by the function
$$$P(D)=10D​+1$$$
where $D$ is the distance in metres below sea
level and $P$ is measured in atmospheres.
A submarine cruising near the surface is submerged according to the
function
$$$D(t)=10+5t$$$
where $t$ is measured in minutes and $D$ is
the distance the submarine is below sea level, measured in
metres.


Find the composite function $P∘D$ and explain what it means in
the
context of this question[3]



Find and interpret $(P∘D)(10)$.[2]
list.markScheme:
The composite function can be expressed as
$$$(P∘D)(t)​=P(D(t))=P(10+5t)=1010+5t​+1=2+2t​​(1)​$$$
$$$This composite function represents the ocean pressure (in atmospheres) outside the submarine at time t minutes.​$$$


Substituting $t=10$ in (1), we get
$$$(P∘D)(10)​=2+210​=7​​$$$
$$$This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.​$$$

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
Let $f(x)=41​x2−2$ and $g(x)=x2−4$, for
$x∈R$.


Show that $(f∘g)(x)=41​x4−2x2+2$. [2]



On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y=(f∘g)(x)$, for
$0≤x≤3$. [3]





![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c14b02c2-8458-4f34-a816-a5c569f5f2fc/images/ceb2f6e6-5725-4682-8f4f-1fb5b9e8117e/b4ef7d37b745cb564b996b9d79dff67b636cf799.svg)



The equation $(f∘g)(x)=k$ has exactly two solutions,
for $0≤x≤3$. Find
the possible values of $k$. [3]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$(f∘g)(x)​=f(g(x))=f(x2−4)=41​(x2−4)2−2=41​(x4−8x2+16)−2=41​x4−2x2+2​​$$$


If we draw the graph of $y=(f∘g)(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we
have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c14b02c2-8458-4f34-a816-a5c569f5f2fc/images/3cea73bc-198a-4cce-8863-df5d6b4c9bb7/35e596bf685bd72ab7dad8286b0830ba0c592c52.svg)




The line $y=k$ intersects the graph of $y=(f∘g)(x)$
exactly at two points when $−2<k≤2$.
Hence the equation $(f∘g)(x)=k$ has exactly two solutions
when  $−2<k≤2​$

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
A tyre manufacturing company has found that the number of tyres it
produces, $N$, can be modelled by the function
$$$N(t)=3t−9$$$
where $t$
is the number of hours the factory operates per day, with a minimum of 3
hours.
The profit the company makes, $P$, in dollars, depends on the number of
tyres produced, and is modelled by the function
$$$P(N)=60N−850$$$
where
$N$ is the number of tyres produced.


Find the company's profit or loss if it operates for $6$ hours per
day.[2]



Find the company's profit in terms of the hours of operation per
day, $t$.[2]



Determine the number of hours the company needs to operate the
factory per day in order to earn a positive profit. Give your answer
to the nearest hour.[2]
list.markScheme:
Substituting $t=6$ in $N(t)$, we get
$$$N(6)​=3(6)−9=9​$$$
Thus, the profit is given by P(9)
$$$P(9)​=60(9)−850=−310​$$$
Therefore, operating $6$
hours a day, the company has a loss:
$$−310​$


The profit in terms of the hours of operation per day can be found
by the composite function $P∘N$. Hence, we get
$$$(P∘N)(t)​=P(N(t))=P(3t−9)=60(3t−9)−850(P∘N)(t)=180t−1390​(1)​$$$


The company has a positive profit if (1) is greater than 0. Hence
$$$(P∘N)(t)180t−1390tt​>0>0>1801390​>7.72.​$$$
Therefore, the
factory needs to operate
$8​$
hours per day in order for the company to earn a positive profit.

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined by
$$$f(x)={4x−1−x2+x+3​ifif​x≥1,x<1.​​$$$


Determine whether or not $f$ is continuous at $x=1$. [2]



The graph of the function $g$ is obtained by applying the following
transformations
to the graph of $f$:
$$$​a horizontal translation 2 units to the left, followed bya reflection in the x-axis, followed bya vertical stretch by a factor of 3.​$$$

Find $g(x)$. [4]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$f(1)​==​4(1)−13​$$$
and
$$$x→1−lim​f(x)​==​−12+1+33​$$$
Hence
$f is continuous at x=1​$


If we translate the graph of $y=f(x)$ horizontally $2$ units to
the left, we get
$$$f(x+2)={4x+7−(x+2)2+x+5​ifif​x≥−1,x<−1.​​$$$
If we reflect the graph of
$y=f(x+2)$ in the $x$-axis, we obtain
$$$−f(x+2)={−4x−7(x+2)2−x−5​ifif​x≥−1,x<−1.​​$$$
If we stretch the graph of
$y=−f(x+2)$ vertically by a factor of $3$, we find
$$$−3f(x+2)={−12x−213(x+2)2−3x−15​ifif​x≥−1,x<−1.​​$$$
Hence the function $g$ is defined
by
$$$g(x)={−12x−213(x+2)2−3x−15​ifif​x≥−1,x<−1.​​​$$$

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
A town is planning to construct a jogging path in a grass field
$170$ m long and $70$ m
wide. The path is to be the shape of a rectangle with two semicircles of
radius $x$, as shown in the diagram. The sides of the rectangle
connecting the circles are to be $100$ m long.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/65b7adec-96d0-405d-bd92-b10fc425e8d5/images/8c94d818-8318-43d4-a5bd-1126ae8aab6c/22448faee8b9c6574b3fdefa8505f67030a94583.svg)




Write down a function, $P$, (in metres) for the perimeter of the
jogging path, in terms of the radius, $x$.[1]



Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the
dimensions of the grass field.[2]



Find an equation for the inverse function $P−1(x)$. Express your
answer in the form $P−1(x)=mx+c$.[2]



The designers of the path are deciding whether the total length of the
path should be $300$ m,
$400$ m, or $500$ m. The
designers want to maximise the perimeter of the path, but fit the path
in the grass field.

Determine which length is most suitable, given the
dimensions of the grass field.[2]
list.markScheme:
The perimeter for the path is the sum of the two straight sides
connecting the circles and the perimeter of a complete circle of
radius $x$. We get
$$$P(x)=200+2πx​$$$


The length of the path will be $100+2x$ and its width $2x$.
Therefore we require $100+2x≤170$ and $2x≤70$. Hence
$$$Domain: 0<x≤35.​​$$$
For
the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=200$ and
$P(35)=200+70π$. We get
$$$Range: 200≤P(x)≤200+70π.​​$$$


Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows
$$$yxy​=200+2πx=200+2πy=2πx−200​P−1(x)=2π1​x−π100​​​$$$


For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P−1(P)$, then the length and width of the running
track can be calculated, as shown in the following table.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/65b7adec-96d0-405d-bd92-b10fc425e8d5/images/282aeb49-7c34-4d6f-82ac-e270f942f1f3/8985560368df68be350c8eca5afbe5b19a733963.svg)


From the table, we can see that the largest perimeter of the options
that still fit inside the grass field dimensions is
$$$P=400m.​$$$

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
Harry is planning on constructing a glass window in one of the outer
walls of his house. The dimensions of the wall space available are 2m x
2m. Harry wants the window to be in the shape shown in the diagram
below. The bottom section is a rectangle and the top part is a
semicircle of radius $x$ m. Harry wants the
height of the rectangle to be fixed at 1 m.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bbc6b0f-8f28-44ce-aae9-1a77840548c5/images/1970cc7c-4fb4-47c4-8b78-0b174bc78816/4b81f49038bd3a70fed3ed55e752da67f426bdf2.svg)




Write down a function $P$ (in metres) for the perimeter of the
window in terms of the radius, $x$.[1]



Determine the domain and range of $P$, taking into consideration the
dimensions of the available wall.[2]



Find an equation for the inverse function $P−1(x)$.[2]



Harry wants to maximise the size of the window, however the window frame
that covers the perimeter of the window can only be 5, 6, or 7 metres
long, due to manufacturing restrictions.

Determine which perimeter length is the best option for
Harry.[2]
list.markScheme:
The perimeter for the window is the sum of the three sides of the
rectangle and the semicircle, thus we get
$$$P(x)​=Rectangle width+2×Rectangle height+Semicircle=2x+2(1)+2​2​πx​P(x)=2+(2+π)x​​$$$


The width of the window will be $2x$ and the height $1+x$.
Therefore, we require $2x≤2$ and $1+x≤2$.
Hence
$$$Domain: 0≤x≤1.​​$$$
Now
for the range, the function $P(x)$ is increasing and $P(0)=2$ and
$P(1)=4+π$. Therefore,
$$$Range: 2≤P(x)≤4+π.​​$$$


Let's denote $P(x)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $x$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows
$$$yxy​=2+(2+π)x=2+(2+π)y=(2+π)x−2​P−1(x)=(2+π)x−2​​​$$$


For each of the proposed perimeters $P$, we can find the radius
value $x$ as $x=P−1(P)$, then the length and width of the window
can be calculated, as shown in the following table


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bbc6b0f-8f28-44ce-aae9-1a77840548c5/images/2db4d8fa-3dad-4595-94a4-c7663a5dbf7c/95900dceeb57876cf3bec3ce67dc138811471933.svg)


From the table, we can see that the perimeter that maximizes the
dimension of the window that fits in the wall is
$$$P=7m.​$$$

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
Let $f(x)=x+15​$, for $x=−1$.

For the graph of $f$, find:


the $x$-intercept;


the $y$-intercept;


the equation of the vertical asymptote. [5]





Let $g(x)=x−3$, for $x∈R$. The graphs of $f$ and $g$
intersect at points A and B.


Find the coordinates of A and B. [5]



Find the equation of the straight line that passes through
A and B,
giving your answer in the form $y=mx+c$. [3]



Write down the gradient of the line that is perpendicular
to the line
passing through A and B. [2]
list.markScheme:
Since the equation $f(x)=0$ has no solutions, there are
$no x-intercepts​$


Evaluating $f(x)=x+15​$ for $x=0$, we have
$$$f(0)​=0+15​=5​$$$
Hence the $y$-intercept is
$P(0,5)​$


We have
$$$x+1x​=0=0=−1​$$$
Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$x=−1​$




Solving the equation $f(x)=g(x)$ for $x$, we have
$$$x+15​5500x​=x−3=(x+1)(x−3)=x2−2x−3=x2−2x−8=(x+2)(x−4)=−2,4​$$$
Evaluating $g(x)=x−3$
for $x=−2$ and $x=4$, we find
$$$yy​==​g(−2)g(4)​==​−51​$$$
Hence we find
$A(−2,−5)​$
and
$B(4,1)​$


Using the gradient formula with A$(−2,−5)$ and B$(4,1)$, we have
$$$mAB​​=x2​−x1​y2​−y1​​=4−(−2)1−(−5)​=1​$$$
Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
A$(−2,−5)$ and $m=1$, we get
$$$y−y1​y−(−5)y+5​=m(x−x1​)=(1)(x−(−2))=x+2​$$$
$$$y=x−3​$$$


$m⊥AB​=−1​$

list.content:
[Maximum marks: 10]
The function $f(x)=asin(bx)+c$ where $0≤x≤π$ and $a,b,c∈R$ is shown below.

The domain of $f(x)$ is restricted to $2π​≤x≤k$, where $k∈R$. This restriction allows an inverse to exist.

Find the largest possible value of $k$. [2]


Another function is defined as $g(x)=−2f(21​x)+3$.

Determine the coordinates of the first maximum value of $g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
To find the value of $a$, which is known as the amplitude, we must find half of the vertical distance between the maximum and minimum values.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/a928181a-4fcd-4ea9-b71e-dc8f5cea02c9/AA1154a.JPEG)


We can see from the diagram that the curve is a reflection of $sinx$ in the $x−$axis, therefore the value of $a$ must be negative.
$$$hack​A1​$$$
Therefore
$$$a​=−23−(−1)​=−2​​R1​$$$


To find the  value of $c$ we must find the $y−$value half way between the maximum and minimum values.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/f6143e17-9146-4ce4-9c33-b01bced64c56/AA1154b.JPEG)


Therefore
$$$c​=23+(−1)​=1​​A1​$$$


To find $b$ we use the formula $T=b2π​$.
We can use the diagram to find $T$ and see that $2T​$ is the $x−$distance between the maximum and minimum values.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/c7dc5b6a-813a-4ffb-bafd-b8fb49ff2f45/AA1154c%20(1).JPEG)


Hence
$$$2T​TT​=(2π​−6π​)=2(2π​−6π​)=32π​​A1​$$$
Using this value of $T$ and the formula stated above we can find $b$.
$$$32π​b​=b2π​=3​​A1​$$$




For an inverse to exist the function must be one-to-one, this means it must pass the horizontal line test. We can see this is satisfied by the red part of $f(x)$  shown below
$$$hack​M1​$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/2b4f5cbc-7374-4bd7-a0b3-ee6657792bc7/AA1154inv.JPEG)


We can see that if we add one complete time period to $6π​$ we will get $k$, hence
$$$k​=6π​+32π​=65π​​​A1​$$$


First we split the vertical and horizontal transformations.
The inner function of $f$ is the horizontal transformations and everything else is vertical.
$$$​−2f(21​x)+3Vertical×−2+3​​Horizontal÷2​$$$
Lets do the vertical transformations first. We don't need to transform the entire function. It is easier to identify a single point and transform that.
Notice that we are multiplying by a negative number, that means $g$ will be a vertical reflection of $f$.
Therefore the first maximum point of $g$ will be the image of the transformation of the first minimum point of $f$.
$$$hack​M1​$$$
Therefore we need to apply our transformations to the point $(6π​,−1)$.
We transform the $y$-coordinate by $×−2$ and then $+3$, therefore the transformed $y$-coordinate is $−1×−2+3=5$.
We transform the $x$-coordinate by $×1/21​$.therefore the transformed $x$-coordinate is $6π​×2=3π​$.
Therefore $the first maximum of g(x) has coordinates (3π​,5).​$
$$$hack​A1A1​$$$

list.title: Question 42
list.content:
Let $f(x)=ax3+bx2+cx+d$, for $x∈R$, where
$a,b,c,d∈Q$. The diagram below shows part of the graph of
$y=f(x)$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d78a10f2-621e-426c-91f2-9dea87dbacc5/images/89842500-91d4-4b78-a494-6ce2510b4acf/f2e9d58912ae2f10d7fdf9d12ee3b7594c2c45fb.svg)




Using the information shown in the diagram, find the values of $a$,
$b$, $c$ and $d$.[4]



Let $g(x)=−43​f(−2x+1)$.


Find the coordinates of the points where the graph of $y=g(x)$
intercepts the $x$-axis.


Find the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y=g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
From the diagram, we see that the roots of the polynomial equation
$f(x)=0$ are $−3$, $−1$ and $3$.
Hence, using the factor theorem, we have
$$$f(x)​=a(x−3)(x+1)(x+3)=a(x2−9)(x+1)=a(x3+x2−9x−9)(1)​$$$
If we substitute
$x=0$ in the expression $(1)$, we get
$$$f(0)−3a​=a(03+02−9(0)−9)=−9a[since f(0)=−3]=31​​$$$
If we substitute $a=1/3$ in the
expression $(1)$, we obtain
$$$f(x)​=31​(x3+x2−9x−9)=31​x3+31​x2−3x−3​$$$
Hence we find
$a=b=31​​$
and  $c=d=−3​$




Solving the equation $g(x)=0$ for $x$, we find
$$$−43​f(−2x+1)f(−2x+1)−2x+1−2xx​=0=0=−3,−1,3=−4,−2,2=−1,1,2​$$$
Hence
the coordinates of the $x$-intercepts of the graph of $y=g(x)$
are
$$$(−1,0),(1,0),(2,0)​​$$$


Evaluating $y=g(x)$ for $x=0$, we find
$$$y​=g(0)=−43​f(2(0)+1)=−43​f(1)=−43​[31​(1)3+31​(1)2−3(1)−3]=−43​[−316​]=4​$$$
Hence the $y$-intercept of the graph of
$y=g(x)$ is
$P(0,4)​$

list.title: Question 43
list.content:
Consider $f(x)=21​−ln(x2−4​)$.


Find the largest possible domain $D$ for $f$ to be a function.
[2]



The function $f$ is defined by
$f(x)=21​−ln(x2−4​)$, for $x∈D$.


Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, showing clearly the
equations of asymptotes and the coordinates of any intercepts with
the axes. [3]



Explain why $f$ is an even function. [1]



Explain why the inverse function $f−1$ does not exist.
[1]



The function $g$ is defined by
$g(x)=21​−ln(x2−4​)$, for
$x∈(2,∞)$.

Find the inverse function $g−1$ and state its domain.
[4]
list.markScheme:
The square root function is defined on $[0,∞)$ and natural
logarithm function is defined on $(0,∞)$.
Hence $f$ is a function if
$$$x2−4​x2−4x2∣x∣x<−2​>0>0>4>2orx>2​$$$
Hence the largest possible domain for $f$ to be a function is
$$$D=(−∞,−2)∪(2,∞)​​$$$


If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/18ea91ad-1794-4924-860f-5cce1a2aaaa5/images/52aadecb-f956-431e-9b31-87bfc4bc127b/c292af76cbb30669709b70ec8dbfa255472cb0f7.svg)




$The function f is even because its graph is symmetric about the y-axis.​$
OR
$The function f is even because it satisfies f(x)=f(−x) for all x∈D.​$


$The inverse function f−1 does not exist because f is not bijective.​$


If we solve the equation $(g∘g−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=g−1(x)$, we get
$$$g(g−1(x))g(y)21​−ln(y2−4​)ln(y2−4​)y2−4​y2−4y2y​=x=x=x=21​−x=e(21​−x)=e2(21​−x)=e1−2x+4=e1−2x+4​​$$$
Hence an expression for $g−1$ is
$g−1(x)=e1−2x+4​​$
The domain of $g−1$ is
$R​$

list.title: Question 44
list.content:
Let $f(x)=x4−x3−5x2+3x+2$, for $x∈R$.


Solve the inequality $f(x)<0$. [3]



For the graph of $y=f(x)$, find the coordinates of the local
maximum point. Round your answers to three significant figures.
[3]



The domain of $f$ is now restricted to $[a,b]$ where
$a,b∈R$.




Write down the smallest value of $a<0$ and the largest value
of $b>0$ for which $f$ has an inverse. Give your answers
correct to three significant figures.


For these values of $a$ and $b$, sketch the graphs of $y=f(x)$
and $y=f−1(x)$ on the same set of axes, showing clearly the
coordinates of the end points of each curve.


Solve the equation $f−1(x)=−1$. [6]
list.markScheme:
If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4511e74b-84ed-4f18-954c-18a8e7a56dc2/images/24541222-4ef2-4f83-8869-c493d5ca3b7d/9444e78d503e38688d4c8ecfe5c29f2d0705556f.svg)


From the diagram, we see that $f$ is positive on the intervals
$(−∞,−2)$, $(−0.414,1)$ and $(2.41,∞)$, and negative on
$(−2,−0.414)$ and $(1,2.41)$.
Hence the set of solutions to the inequality $f(x)<0$ is
$$$(−2,−0.414)∪(1,2.41)​​$$$


From the diagram, we see that the graph of $y=f(x)$ has a local
maximum at point B.
Hence the coordinates of the local maximum point are
$(0.285,2.43)​$




From the diagram, we see that $f$ is a bijection if its domain
is restricted to $[−1.14,0.285]$ or $[0.285,1.87]$.
Hence $f$ has an inverse if
$a=−1.41​$
and  $b=0.285​$


The graph of $y=f−1(x)$ is a reflection of the graph of
$y=f(x)$ across the line $y=x$.
Hence, if we sketch the graphs of $y=f(x)$ and $y=f−1(x)$
on the same set of axes, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4511e74b-84ed-4f18-954c-18a8e7a56dc2/images/81733c2d-4f9c-47f5-bd1c-45eb231fe561/b6185b0f42f1522008f7c0707456fd536c854029.svg)




If we solve the equation $f−1(x)=−1$ for $x$, we obtain
$$$f(f−1(x))​=f(−1)​$$$
$$$x=−4​[since f(f−1(x))=x]$$$

list.title: Question 45
list.content:
The graph of $y=f(x)$ for $0≤x≤6$ is shown below


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/d9b698f4-a101-40b3-a118-dbc3aa80bdc7/AA1279-q1.JPEG)


The odd function $h(x)$ has the domain $−6≤x≤6$ and $h(x)=2f(x)$ for $0≤x≤6$.

Sketch $h(x)$ on the axes above.[2]


$f(x)$ is shown again below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/3a60566c-11b7-4cc2-ac58-301a1f0b734a/AA1279-q2.JPEG)



Sketch the graph of $y=[f(x)]2$ on the axes above.[3]


$f(x)$ is shown one more time below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/6712f3c3-7980-49b2-be9d-09510dd7213d/AA1279-q3.JPEG)



Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)1​$ on the axes above.[3]
list.markScheme:
Let's start with graphing $y=2f(x)$.
This is a vertical stretch by a scale factor of 2.
The distance of all $y−$coordinates from the $x−$axis are multiplied by two.
The key point $(2,2)$ will become $(2,4)$.  This is shown in the graph below in $red$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/ee8f2b59-189d-4582-b80f-8543d1539c11/AA1279-a1.JPEG)


The definition of an odd function is $f(−x)=−f(x)$. This transformation represents rotational symmetry of order $2$ about the origin which is equivalent to performing two reflections, one in each axis, in any order.
Therefore, to complete the rest of the graph of $h(x)$, we can either take the graph of $y=2f(x)$ and rotate it $180∘$ about the origin or perform two reflections, one in each axis. Both result in the same final position.
If we consider the reflection approach. First, we perform $f(x)→f(−x)$, this is a reflection in the $y−$axis. This is the dotted blue line shown in the following graph.
Then we consider $f(−x)→−f(−x)$, this is a reflection in the $x−$axis.
This fully transformed part is shown in solid $blue$ in the following graph.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/e98b48c5-6b88-483c-9505-e090a80ebdda/AA1279-a2.JPEG)


The final graph of $y=h(x)$ is shown below


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/36471d45-1f48-4d32-ac28-33498e303129/AA1279-a3.JPEG)


$$$Correct points at (−2,−4) and (−6,0)​Correct transformation(s)​​A1A1​$$$


First, let's look at the section of the graph $0≤x≤2$.
We can use the properties of the transformation $[f(x)]2$ to identify some key points.
We know that if $f(x)=0$ then $[f(x)]2=0$.
We also know that if $f(x)=1$ then $[f(x)]2=1$.
It is important to also realise that if $−1<f(x)<1$ then $[f(x)]2<f(x)$.
Therefore between $0<x<1$ then $[f(x)]2<f(x)$.
Using the end point of the first part of the curve we can see that $[f(2)]2=4$.
Using the key points $(0,0)$, $(1,1)$ and $(2,4)$ we can sketch the transformed curve, shown in $red$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/1850a5f9-cc57-42c9-aced-4f5076f93f70/AA1279-a4.JPEG)


Now, let's look at the section of the graph $2≤x≤6$.
We know the second section will start at $(2,4)$ and finish at $(6,0)$.
Using the property if $f(x)=1$ then $[f(x)]2=1$ we know the curve will intersect the original function at $f(x)=1$.
Which we can see is at $(4,1)$.
It is important to clearly show on the graph that $[f(x)]2<f(x)$ when $0<f(x)<1$.
With this in mind, using the key points $(2,4)$, $(1,4)$ and $(6,0)$ we can sketch the second part, shown in $blue$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/df6ea7d7-12e8-4c02-9e9e-59b469c720e1/AA1279-a5.JPEG)


The final graph of $y=[f(x)]2$ is shown below


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/d8f9fbfb-5406-4219-9359-a6a3e373e1ae/AA1279-a6.JPEG)


$$$​Correct shape​f(x)=[f(x)]2 when f(x)=0,1​[f(x)]2 is less than f(x) when 0<f(x)<1​​A1A1A1​$$$


Let's start by drawing the vertical asymptotes.
They will occur at the $x$-intercepts of $f(x)$ which are $x=0$ and $x=6$. Shown below as the dotted red vertical lines


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/e1ad22e1-6249-4f31-ba13-092dd647afbb/AA1279-a7.JPEG)


Let's consider the key point $(2,2)$, after the transformation this point will become $(2,21​)$.
Considering the asymptotes, we can see that as $x→0$ and $x→6$ then $f(x)→0$ (from the positive direction) therefore $f(x)1​→∞+$.
Hence we get the graph below in $blue$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/4d398d26-b01f-4f29-993f-5ab558c1e147/AA1279-a8.JPEG)


The final graph of $y=f(x)1​$ is shown below


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/c11d79ea-8c87-4a3e-9c0e-bcd8cf6583d1/AA1279-a9.JPEG)


$$$​Correct asymptotes​Correct shape​Correct minimum point at (2,21​)​​A1A1A1​$$$

list.title: Question 46
list.content:
It is given that $f(x)=2x4+5x3+ax2+bx+4$, for
$x∈R$, where $a,b∈Z$.


Given that $x2+x−2$ is a factor of $f(x)$, find the values of
$a$ and $b$. [4]



Factorise $f(x)$ into a product of linear factors. [4]



Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, labeling the maximum and minimum
points and the $x$ and $y$ intercepts. [3]



Using your graph, state the range of values of $c$ for which
$f(x)=c$ has exactly four real roots. [2]
list.markScheme:
Factorising $x2+x−2$ into a product of linear factors, we have
$$$x2+x−2=(x−1)(x+2)​$$$
Hence $(x−1)$ and $(x+2)$
are both factors of $f(x)$.
Hence, using the factor theorem, we get
$$$f(1)2(1)4+5(1)3+a(1)2+b(1)+42+5+a+b+4a+b​=0=0=0=−11(1)​$$$
Using the factor theorem again, we obtain
$$$f(−2)2(−2)4+5(−2)3+a(−2)2+b(−2)+432−40+4a−2b+44a−2b2a−b​=0=0=0=4=2(2)​$$$
Hence, solving the system of
two linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find
$$$a=−3​ and b=−8​​$$$


If we divide $2x4+5x3−3x2−8x+4$ by $x2+x−2$, we have
Hence we get
$$$f(x)​=2x4+5x3−3x2−8x+4=(x2+x−2)(2x2+3x−2)=(x−1)(x+2)(2x−1)(x+2)=(x−1)(2x−1)(x+2)2​​$$$


If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1bd4cd72-a9fa-45a6-960b-36cd2036ef37/images/aab0e32b-f24b-45b1-918c-1af7fb3e580b/fee6121260f114c0cc689969551419dd8b20d6fc.svg)




From the diagram, we see that the equation $f(x)=c$ has exactly
four real
roots when
$0<c<6.92​$

list.title: Question 47
list.content:
Sketch the curve $y=−​x−25​​$ and line
$y=−x−4$ on the same axes,
clearly indicating any $x$ and $y$ intercepts and any asymptotes.
[3]



Find the exact solutions to the equation $x+4=∣x−2∣5​$.
[5]
list.markScheme:
Let $f(x)=−​x−25​​$ where $x∈R$,
$x=2$.
Since $f(x)<0$ for all $x∈R$, $x=2$, the curve
$y=f(x)$ has no $x$-intercepts.
Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we obtain
$$$y​=f(0)=−​−25​​=−25​​$$$
Hence the point A$(0,−5/2)$ is the
$y$-intercept of the curve $y=f(x)$.
We have
$$$x→±∞lim​f(x)=0$$$
Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal asymptote of the curve
$y=f(x)$.
The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x=2$. Hence the line $x=2$
is a vertical asymptote of the curve $y=f(x)$.
The $x$ and $y$ intercepts of the line $y=−4−x$ are B$(−4,0)$ and
C$(0,−4)$.
If we sketch the curve $y=f(x)$ and line $y=−x−4$ on the same
axes, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3ce10e6d-6009-49da-a002-42ae1d773968/images/2248acaa-10a6-4043-b8a6-84823cf01ad6/38ce371d4e9621963b29074adf6413c8b9f71c7c.svg)




If we solve the equation $x+4=∣x−2∣5​$ for $x<2$, we
find
$$$x+4(x+4)(x−2)x2+2x−8x2+2x−3(x+3)(x−1)x​=−x−25​[since x−2<0]=−5=−5=0=0=−3,1​$$$
If we simplify the equation
$x+4=∣x−2∣5​$ for $x>2$, we have
$$$x+4(x+4)(x−2)x2+2x−8x2+2x−13​=x−25​[since x−2>0]=5=5=0​$$$
Hence, using the quadratic
formula, we find
$$$x​=2−2+22−4(1)(−13)​​[since x>2]=2−2+214​​=−1+14​​$$$
Hence the
exact solutions to the equation $x+4=∣x−2∣5​$ are  $−3,1,−1+14​​$

list.title: Question 48
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined by $f(x)=1+x+34x​$, for
$x=−3$.


Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, indicating clearly any asymptotes
and
points of intersection with the $x$ and $y$ axes. [4]



Find an expression for $f−1$. [4]



Find all values of $x$ for which $f(x)=f−1(x)$. [3]



Solve the inequality $∣f(x)∣<2$. [4]



Solve the inequality $f(∣x∣)<2$. [2]
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$1+x+34x​x+35x+3​5x+3x​=0=0=0=−53​​$$$
Hence the point
P$(−3/5,0)$ is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we obtain
$$$y​=f(0)=1​$$$
Hence the point Q$(0,1)$ is the $y$-intercept of
the graph of $y=f(x)$.
We have
$$$x→±∞lim​f(x)​=1+14​=5​$$$
Hence the line $y=5$ is a horizontal asymptote
of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x=−3$. Hence the line
$x=−3$
is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
If we sketch of the graph of $y=f(x)$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b02f9456-fc87-4d72-8046-b8ad6f17fd88/images/80e5d1bc-25e1-48da-ad0b-cf11c4df076c/a4ee5024679811f4302b4cf52d17f68170c60827.svg)




If we solve the equation $(f∘f−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=f−1(x)$, we find
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)​=x=x​$$$
$$$1+y+34y​y+35y+3​5y+3(5−x)yy​=x=x=xy+3x=3x−3=5−x3x−3​​$$$
Hence an expression for
$f−1$ is
$f−1(x)=5−x3x−3​​$


If we solve the equation $f(x)=f−1(x)$ for $x$, we get
$$$f(x)1+x+34x​x+35x+3​(5x+3)(5−x)25x−5x2+15−3x−8x2+16x+24​=f−1(x)=5−x3x−3​=5−x3x−3​=(3x−3)(x+3)=3x2+9x−3x−9=0​$$$
$$$x2−2x−3(x+1)(x−3)​=0=0​$$$
$$$x=−1,3​$$$


We have
$$$−2f−1(−2)​<<​∣f(x)∣f(x)x​<<<​22f−1(2)[since f−1(f(x))=x]​​$$$
Evaluating $y=f−1(x)$ for $x=−2$,
we get
$$$f−1(−2)​=5−(−2)3(−2)−3​=−79​​$$$
Evaluating $y=f−1(x)$ for
$x=2$, we obtain
$$$f−1(2)​=5−23(2)−3​=1​$$$
Hence the set of solutions to the inequality
$∣f(x)∣<2$ is
$−79​<x<1​$


If we solve the inequality $f(∣x∣)<2$ for $∣x∣$, we get
$$$1+∣x∣+34∣x∣​∣x∣+34∣x∣​4∣x∣3∣x∣∣x∣​<2<1<∣x∣+3<3<1​$$$
Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $f(∣x∣)<2$ is
$−1<x<1​$

list.title: Question 49
list.content:
Consider the function $f(x)=5xex+1$.
The function has a single point of inflexion at $A$.


Show that the point of inflexion  of $f(x)$ occurs when $x=−2$. [3]



Sketch $f(x)$ on the grid below, label point $A$ and any asymptotes.[1]



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04090a8e-6d70-4a75-a5e4-341287b09a7d/images/0957c93a-b030-4309-ad29-4635f77a12cf/AA1156_q.JPEG)




The line $g(x)=mx+c$ passes through $A$ for all values of $m$ and $c$.


Evaluate $m$ when $g(x)$ is tangent to $f(x)$ at point $A$.


Hence find the range of values of $m$ for which $f(x)=g(x)$ has exactly $3$ solutions. [4]
list.markScheme:
Recognise that inflexion points occur when $f′′(x)=0$.
$$$hack​M1​$$$
Use the product rule to differentiate $f(x)$.
$$$f′(x)​=(5x)′ex+5x(ex)′=5ex+5xex​$$$
Now we use a similar method to find $f′′(x)$
$$$f′′(x)​=5ex+5ex+5xex=10ex+5xex​A1​$$$
Now we solve the equation $f′′(x)=0$
$$$02+x​=10ex+5xex=5ex(2+x)=0x=−2​...as required.​A1​$$$


Here is the sketch of $f(x)$ with the required elements highlighted


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04090a8e-6d70-4a75-a5e4-341287b09a7d/images/938f99b3-82b2-4be3-8842-3773b2f2b666/AA1156_s0.JPEG)


$$$hack​A1​$$$




Recognise that $m=f′(−2)$.
Using the G.D.C. we can find $m$
$$$f′(−2)​=−0.6767...m=−0.677​​A1​$$$


The tangent at $A$ intersects $f(x)$ at one point.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04090a8e-6d70-4a75-a5e4-341287b09a7d/images/61f12b76-8fd9-4fec-a868-4affacf96f18/AA1156_s1.JPEG)


Therefore when $m=−0.6767...$ there is one solution for $f(x)=g(x)$.
As $m$ approaches $0$ we see below that there are $3$ solutions to $f(x)=g(x)$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04090a8e-6d70-4a75-a5e4-341287b09a7d/images/58cf6bf2-796c-49e5-845f-715535e686dc/AA1156_s2.JPEG)


When $m=0$ $g(x)$ is parallel to the asymptote, we can see below that there are $2$ solutions to $f(x)=g(x)$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04090a8e-6d70-4a75-a5e4-341287b09a7d/images/f5ae73cb-47b3-4254-8cf5-b5fd67a36f92/AA1156_s3.JPEG)


Therefore there are $3$ solutions to $f(x)=g(x)$ when $−0.677<m<0​$
A1A1 Correct end points 
A1 $$Correct inequality signs

list.title: Question 50
list.content:
Consider the function $f(x)=6x2−7x+2$.

Fully factorise $f(x)$. [2]



Another function is defined as $g(x)=lnx$.
A third function is defined as $h(x)=(g∘f)(x)$.

Hence, determine the domain of $h(x)$. [3]



The value $a$ is added to $f(x)$, where $a∈R$.
For the domain of $h(x)$ to be $x∈R$ then $a>k$.
The minimum value of $k$ is $amin​$.

Find $amin​$ [3]



Now the value $b$ is added to $f(x)$, where $b∈R$ and $b>amin​$.

Find the value of $b$ such that the vertex of $h(x)$ lies on the $x−$axis. Give your answer to $4$ significant figures. [3]
list.markScheme:
We will use the grouping method to factorise.
$$$a×c​=2×6=12​$$$
Therefore we need to find two numbers that sum to $−7$ and multiply to give $12$. These are $−3$ and $−4$.
Therefore, we can then rewrite $−7x$ as $−3x−4x$. Hence
$$$6x2−7x+2​=6x2−3x−4x+2​(M1)​$$$
We then factorise the resulting expression into two groups
$$$​=3x(2x−1)−2(2x−1)=(2x−1)(3x−2)​​A1​$$$


This is a composite function in which we form $h(x)$ by substituting $f(x)$ into $g(x)$. Therefore
$$$h(x)​=ln(6x2−7x+2)​A1​$$$
We can now sketch $h(x)$ on our G.D.C.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ad3c15f-2574-4451-89c3-6131f920fec6/images/af7c0b7c-4bcd-4f99-bacf-0b4ca2abe01e/AA1169_a%20(2).JPEG)


$h(x)$ has two vertical asymptotes and these occur when $h(x)=ln0$. Hence $f(x)=0$.
$$$hack​(M1)​$$$
Using the answer from part (a) we can find their equations.
$$$(2x−1)(3x−2)x​=0=21​,32​​$$$
The red arrows on the image above show the domain of $h(x)$.
Therefore the $domain of h(x) is x<21​ and x>32​​$
$$$hack​A1​$$$


The following image shows $f(x)$ and $h(x)$ together on the same axes.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ad3c15f-2574-4451-89c3-6131f920fec6/images/864e7db3-f2fc-45ed-ae8d-6c54c1f1a58c/AA1169_c%20(3).JPEG)


Notice that $h(x)$ is undefined when $f(x)<0$, this is the dark blue part of $f(x)$.
Hence we need to shift $f(x)$ vertically up $a$ units such that the vertex of $f(x)$ touches the $x−$axis at a single point.
$$$hack​R1​$$$
To do this we must find the minimum value of $f(x)$.
Using a G.D.C. we can find the minimum point of $f(x)$ to be $(0.5833...,−0.04166...)$
$$$hack​(A1)​$$$
Hence $f(x)+0.04166...$ will ensure $f(x)$ intersects the $x−$axis at one point. Ensuring that $f(x)≥0$ for all $x$. This is shown below


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ad3c15f-2574-4451-89c3-6131f920fec6/images/f9e9a35b-66f6-4ba2-a644-2fcd2cd8379f/AA1169_d.JPEG)


Therefore if $a>0.04166...$ then $f(x)>0$ for all $x$ and the domain of $h(x)$ is $x∈R$.
Hence, $amin​=0.0417​$
$$$hack​A1​$$$


Notice from the image in the previous part, that the vertex of $h(x)$ lies on the same vertical line as $f(x)$.
Therefore the equation of the vertical line is $x=0.5833...$ and the final position of the vertex of $h(x)$ must be on the $x−$axis. This is shown below.
$$$hack​(M1)​$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ad3c15f-2574-4451-89c3-6131f920fec6/images/2cb902a1-41ee-439b-9f07-b35d58eb8a60/AA1169_d2.JPEG)


Therefore we need to solve this equation
$$$h(0.5833...)(g∘(f(0.5833...)+b))ln(f(0.5833...)+b)f(0.5833...)+b​=0=0=0(ln1=0)=1​A1​$$$
From part (c) we know that $f(0.5833...)=−0.04166...$ at the vertex of $f(x)$ therefore
$$$b​=1−(−0.04166...)=1.04166...​$$$
Therefore $b=1.042​$.
$$$hack​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 51
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined by $f(x)=e2x−4ex+2$, for
$x∈R$, $x≤a$, where $a∈R$.
Part of the graph of $y=f(x)$ is shown in the following diagram.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4c5c56b3-ccff-4218-8eeb-ed43662a5361/images/6b8a627c-1929-4344-ac27-a9f1d77bd6ab/dc14321f698d30780f4ecaf20c082a22181a9565.svg)




Find the largest value of $a$ such that $f$ has an inverse function.
[3]



For this value of $a$, find an expression for $f−1(x)$, stating
its domain. [5]
list.markScheme:
From the diagram, we see that the $x$-coordinate of the local
minimum point on the graph of $y=f(x)$ is the largest value of $a$
such that $f$ has an inverse function.
We have
$$$f′(x)​=dxd​[e2x−4ex+2]=2e2x−4ex=[2ex][ex−2]​$$$
If we solve the equation $f′(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$[2ex][ex−2]ex−2exx​=0=0=2=ln2​$$$
Hence we find
$a=ln2​$


If we solve the equation $(f∘f−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=f−1(x)$, we obtain
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)e2y−4ey+2[(ey)2−4ey]+2[(ey−2)2−4]+2(ey−2)2ey−2ey−2eyy​=x[where −2≤x<2]=x[where y≤ln2]=x=x=x[by completing the square]=x+2=±x+2​=−x+2​[since y≤ln2]=2−x+2​=ln(2−x+2​)​$$$
Hence we find
$f−1(x)=ln(2−x+2​), for x∈R,−2≤x<2​$

list.title: Question 52
list.content:
This question asks you to investigate some properties of even and odd functions.
Consider the functions $f1​(x)=x35​$ and $f2​(x)=3x2+8$.


Determine whether:


The function $f1​(x)$ is an even function or an odd function,


The function $f2​(x)$ is an even function or an odd function.[4]





Suppose $g(x)$ is a function with domain $R$ and let $h$ and $j$ be the functions
$$$h(x)=2g(x)+g(−x)​,j(x)=2g(x)−g(−x)​​$$$




Show that $g(x)=h(x)+j(x).$


Hence, show that $g(x)$ is the sum of an even and an odd function.[4]





Using the results from part (b), find the even part and the odd part of


$g(x)=x4+4x3+5x2−2x$[3]

Let $f(x)$ be a function that is differentiable for all $x∈R.$


Show that:


if $f(x)$ is an even function, then $f′(x)$ is an odd function


if $f(x)$ is an odd function, then $f′(x)$ is an even function.[4]





Show that if $f(x)$ is an even function defined and differentiable at $x=0,$ then:


$f′(0)=0$,


$f2k+1(0)=0$ for $k∈Z+$,


its Maclaurin series expansion contains only even powers of $x$.[5]





Show that if $f(x)$ is an odd function, then its Maclaurin series expansion contains only odd powers of $x.$ [5]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $f1​$ at $−x$, we get
$$$f1​(−x)​=(−x)35​=−x35​=−f1​(x)​$$$
Since $f1​(−x)=−f1​(x)$, $the function f1​(x) is an odd function.​$


Evaluating $f2​$ at $−x$, we get
$$$f2​(−x)​=3(−x)2+8=3x2+8=f2​(x)​$$$
Since $f2​(−x)=f2​(x),$ $ the function f2​(x) is an even function.​$






Taking the sum of $h$ and $j$, we obtain
$$$h(x)+j(x)​=2g(x)+g(−x)​+2g(x)−g(−x)​=22g(x)​h(x)+j(x)=g(x)​​$$$


Evaluating $h$ at $−x$, we get
$$$h(−x)​=2g(−x)+g(x)​=2g(x)+g(−x)​=h(x)​$$$
Therefore, $h(x)$ is an even function.
Now, evaluating $j$ at $−x$, we get
$$$j(−x)​=2g(−x)−g(x)​=−2g(x)−g(−x)​=−j(x)​$$$
Therefore, $j(x)$ is an odd function.
Since $g(x)=h(x)+j(x)$, any function $g(x)$ can be written as the sum of an even function and an odd function.




Evaluating $g$ at $−x$, we get
$$$g(−x)​=(−x)4+4(−x)3+5(−x)2−2(−x)=x4−4x3+5x2+2x​$$$
From part (b), the even part of $g(x)$ is $h(x)$.
$$$h(x)​=2g(x)+g(−x)​=2(x4+4x3+5x2−2x)+(x4−4x3+5x2+2x)​=22x4+10x2​=x4+5x2​​$$$
The odd part of $g(x)$ is $j(x)$.
$$$j(x)​=2g(x)−g(−x)​=2(x4+4x3+5x2−2x)−(x4−4x3+5x2+2x)​=28x3−4x​=4x3−2x​​$$$




Let's suppose that $f(x)$ is an even function. Thus, we have
$$$f(−x)−f′(−x)f′(−x)​=f(x)=f′(x)=−f′(x)​$$$
Therefore,$ f′(x) is an odd function.​$


Let's suppose that $f(x)$ is an odd function. Thus, we have
$$$f(−x)−f′(−x)f′(−x)​=−f(x)=−f′(x)=f′(x)​$$$
Therefore, $ f′(x) is an even function.​$






By part (d), if $f(x)$ is an even function then $f′(x)$ is an odd function. We get
$$$f′(−0)f′(0)2f′(0)​=−f′(0)=−f′(0)=0f′(0)=0​​$$$


Using part (d) (i), $f(x)$ even $⇒f′(x)$ odd.
Using part (d) (ii), $f′(x)$ odd $⇒f′′(x)$ even.
By iteration, we have that every odd derivative is an odd function and every even derivative is an even function. That is, $f2k+1(x)$ is odd and $f2k(x)$ is even for $k∈Z+$. Hence,
$$$f2k+1(−x)f2k+1(−0)f2k+1(0)2f2k+1(0)​=−f2k+1(x)=−f2k+1(0)=−f2k+1(0)=0f2k+1(0)=0​​$$$


The Maclaurin series expansion of $f(x)$ is
$$$f(x)=f(0)+xf′(0)+2!x2​f′′(0)+3!x3​f(3)(0)+⋯​$$$
From part (ii), $f′(0)=0$ and $f2k+1(0)=0$ for $k∈Z+$, which means that
The only non-zero terms remaining in the Maclaurin series expansion are those of the form $(2k)!x2k​f2k(0)$, those with even powers of $x$, including the constant term.




By part (d), if $f(x)$ is an odd function then $f′(x)$ is an even function and $f′′(x)$ is an odd function. Using parts (d) (i) and (ii), by iteration, every even derivative is an odd function.
We can say that $f2k(x)$ is an odd function for $k∈Z+$. Thus, we have
$$$f2k(−x)f2k(−0)f2k(0)2f2k(0)f2k(0)​=−f2k(x)=−f2k(0)=−f2k(0)=0=0​$$$
The Maclaurin series expansion of $f(x)$ is
$$$f(x)=f(0)+xf′(0)+2!x2​f′′(0)+3!x3​f(3)(0)+⋯​$$$
Therefore the terms with even powers in the Maclaurin series of $f(x)$ vanish and the Maclaurin series of $f(x)$ contains only terms with odd powers of $x$.

list.title: Question 53
list.content:
Let
$f(x)=x4−0.4x3−2.85x2+0.9x+1.35$,
for $x∈R$.


Find the solutions for $f(x)>0$. [3]



For the graph of $y=f(x)$,


find the coordinates of local minimum and maximum points.


find the $x$-coordinates of the points of inflexion. [5]





The domain of $f$ is now restricted to $[a,b]$ where
$a,b∈R+$.




Write down the smallest value of $a>0$ and the largest value
of $b>0$ for which $f$ has an inverse. Give your answers
correct to three significant figures.


For these values of $a$ and $b$, sketch the graphs of $y=f(x)$
and $y=f−1(x)$ on the same set of axes, showing clearly the
coordinates of the end points of each curve.


Solve $f−1(x)=0.5$. [6]





Let $g(x)=32​sin(2x−1)+21​$,
$21​−4π​≤x≤21​+4π​$.




Find an expression for $g−1$ and state its domain.


Solve $(f−1∘g)(x)<0.5$. [8]
list.markScheme:
If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b276ac45-671f-4c75-9dea-a3774fc53f67/images/44e18fcd-818c-481b-aabd-bbc35f210168/245a2a1979fce06233cc54e60878b1e96f11b9d1.svg)


From the diagram, we see that $f$ is positive on the intervals
$(−∞,−1.5)$, $(−0.6,1)$ and $(1.5,∞)$, and negative on
$(−1.5,−0.6)$ and $(1,1.5)$.
Hence the set of solutions to the inequality $f(x)>0$ is
$$$(−∞,−1.5)∪(−0.6,1)∪(1.5,∞)​​$$$




From the diagram, we see that the graph of $y=f(x)$ has a
local
maximum at point A and local minimums at points B and C.
Hence the coordinates of the local max and min points are
$$$local max:local min:​(0.155,1.42)​(−1.13,−1.10)​ and (1.28,−0.322)​​$$$


We have
$$$f(x)f′(x)f′′(x)​=x4−0.4x3−2.85x2+0.9x+1.35=4x3−1.2x2−5.7x+0.9=12x2−2.4x−5.7​$$$
Hence, if we solve the equation
$f′′(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$12x2−2.4x−5.7​=0​$$$
$$$x≈−0.596,0.796​[by using G.D.C.]$$$






From the diagram, we see that $f$ is a bijection if its domain
is restricted to $[−1.13,0.155]$ or $[0.155,1.28]$.
As it is given that $a,b>0$, hence $f$ has an inverse if
$a=0.155​$
and  $b=1.28​$


The graph of $y=f−1(x)$ is the reflection of the graph of
$y=f(x)$ across the line $y=x$.
Hence, if we sketch the graphs of $y=f(x)$ and $y=f−1(x)$
on the same set of axes, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b276ac45-671f-4c75-9dea-a3774fc53f67/images/3ebbda78-45c5-40ce-9d82-70daf75779a2/524a320d1d2563d4a110444319e1f709eb5ee6c6.svg)




If we solve the equation $f−1(x)=0.5$ for $x$, we obtain
$$$f(f−1(x))​=f(0.5)​$$$
$$$x=1.1​[since f(f−1(x))=x]$$$






Solving the equation $(g∘g−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=g−1(x)$, we get
$$$g(g−1(x))g(y)32​sin(2y−1)+21​32​sin(2y−1)sin(2y−1)2y−1y​=x=x=x=22x−1​=46x−3​=arcsin(46x−3​)=21​arcsin(46x−3​)+21​​$$$
Hence an expression for $g−1$ is
$g−1(x)=21​arcsin(46x−3​)+21​​$
The range of $g$ is
$$$[−32​+21​,32​+21​]=[−61​,67​]​$$$
Hence the domain of $g−1$ is
$[−61​,67​]​$


Solving the inequality $(f−1∘g)(x)<0.5$ for $x$, we
get
$$$f−1(g(x))g(x)g(x)xx​<0.5>f(0.5)[since f is decreasing]>1.1>g−1(1.1)[since g−1 is increasing]>1.06​$$$
Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $(f−1∘g)(x)<0.5$ is
$$$(1.06,21​+4π​]​​$$$

list.title: Question 54
list.content:
Consider the function $g(x)=ax3+bx2+cx+d$, where $x∈R$ and
$a$, $b$, $c$, $d∈R.$




Write down an expression for $g′(x)$.


Hence, given that $g−1$ does not exist, show that
$b2−3ac>0.$[3]





Consider the function
$f(x)=2x3​+3x2+6x+29​$




Show that $f−1$ exists.


$f(x)$ can be written in the form $p(x+2)3+q$,
where $p$, $q∈R$. Find the value of $p$ and the
value of $q$.


Hence, find $f−1(x)$.[7]





The graph of $f(x)$ may be obtained by transforming the graph of $y=x3$
using a sequence of three transformations.


State each of the transformations in the order in which
they are applied.[3]



Sketch the graphs of $y=f(x)$ and $y=f−1(x)$ on the same
set of axes, indicating the points where each graph crosses the
coordinate axes.[4]
list.markScheme:
Taking the derivative with respect to $x$, we find
$$$g′(x)​=dxd​[ax3+bx2+cx+d]=3ax2+2bx+c​​$$$


As $g−1$ does not exist, the graph of $g$ should have two
turning points. Thus, the derivative has a strictly positive
discriminant, this is
$$$[discriminant of g′](2b)2−4(3a)(c)4b2−12ac​>0>0[△=b2−4ac]>0b2−3ac>0​​$$$






Using part (a) (ii), we get
$$$(3)2−3(21​)(6)​≯0.​$$$
Therefore, by the contrapositive statement to part (a) (ii), we
deduce $f−1$ exists.


Factorizing the expression for $y=f(x)$, we get
$$$f(x)​=21​(x3+6x2+12x+9)=21​(x3+6x2+12x+8+1)=21​(x+2)3+21​​$$$
Therefore
$p=21​,q=21​​$


If we solve the equation $(f∘f−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=f−1(x)$, we get
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)21​(y+2)3+21​(y+2)3y+2​=x=x=x=2x−1=32x−1​f−1(x)=32x−1​−2​​$$$




We get the following transformations
$$$transformation 1transformation 2transformation 3​:horizontal translation 2 units left​:vertical stretch by a factor of 21​​:vertical translation 21​ units up​​$$$
Note: The horizontal translation can be performed in any step but
the
vertical stretch should be performed before the vertical
translation.


Using the shape of a cubic function, we get

list.title: Question 55
list.content:
A function $f(x)$ is defined by
$f(x)=arccos(x2+1x2−1​)$, $x∈R$.


Show that $f$ is an even function.[1]



Find the equation of the horizontal asymptote to the graph of
$y=f(x)$.[2]





Show that $f′(x)=−x2​(x2+1)2x​$
for $x∈R$, $x=0$.


Using the expression for $f′(x)$ and the result
$x2​=∣x∣$, show that $f$ is increasing for
$x<0$.[9]





A function $g$ is defined by
$g(x)=arccos(x2+1x2−1​)$, $x∈R$,
$x≥0$.


Find the range of $g$. [2]



Find an expression for $g−1(x)$. [4]



State the domain of $g−1(x)$. [1]



Sketch the graph of $y=g−1(x)$. Clearly indicating any
asymptotes with their equations and stating the values of any axes
intercepts.[3]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $f(−x)$, we get
$$$f(−x)​=arccos((−x)2+1(−x)2−1​)=arccos(x2+1x2−1​)=f(x)​$$$
$Therefore, f(x) is an even function​$


Taking the limit as $x$ tends to $±∞$, using the continuity
of the $arccos$ function, we get
$$$x→±∞lim​arccos(x2+1x2−1​)​=arccos(x→±∞lim​x2+1x2−1​)=arccos​x→±∞lim​1+x21​1−x21​​​=arccos(1)=0​$$$
$Therefore y=0 is a horizontal asymptote for the graph of y=f(x)​$




If we calculate the derivative of $f$, we have
$$$f′(x)​=dxd​[arccos(x2+1x2−1​)]=−1−(x2+1x2−1​)2​1​((x2+1)24x​)[by chain rule]=−(x2+1)2(x2+1)2−(x2−1)2​​1​((x2+1)24x​)=−(x2+1)24x2​​1​((x2+1)24x​)=−2x2​x2+1​⋅(x2+1)24x​=−x2​(x2+1)2x​​$$$


$f$ is increasing when $f′(x)>0$. Using that $x2​=∣x∣$,
we get
$$$f′(x)​=−x2​(x2+1)2x​=−∣x∣(x2+1)2x​=⎩⎨⎧​−x2+12​−x2+12​​x<0x>0​​$$$
$Therefore f is increasing over x<0​$




Using G.D.C., we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/40959260-ff44-430d-ba78-56c4196b0ee8/images/739aa0a1-8497-4bf5-9271-580041574b8f/f0c0fbdf08255f11d554923de27f12f77e5813a5.svg)


Hence,$range of g:(0,π]​$


If we solve the equation $(g∘g−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=g−1(x)$, we get
$$$g(g−1(x))g(y)arccos(y2+1y2−1​)y2+1y2−1​(y2+1)cosxy2cosx−y2y2(cosx−1)y2​=x=x=x=cosx=y2−1=−1−cosx=−1−cosx=1−cosx1+cosx​g−1(x)=1−cosx1+cosx​​​cosx=1​$$$


We have
$$$domain of g−1​=range of g=(0,π]​​$$$
